The initial stages of Li2O2 formation during oxygen reduction reaction in Li-O2 batteries: The significance of Li2O2 in charge-transfer reactions within devices Daniela M. Josepetti a Bianca P. Sousa a Simone A.J. Rodrigues b Renato G. Freitas b ⁎ Gustavo Doubek a ⁎ a Advanced Energy Storage Division, LAB, Center for Innovation on New Energies, School of Chemical Engineering, University of Campinas, Av Albert Einstein 500 13083-852, Campinas, SP, Brazil Advanced Energy Storage Division LAB Center for Innovation on New Energies School of Chemical Engineering University of Campinas Av Albert Einstein 500 Campinas SP 13083-852 Brazil Advanced Energy Storage Division, LAB, Center for Innovation on New Energies, School of Chemical Engineering, University of Campinas, Av Albert Einstein 500 13083-852, Campinas, SP, Brazil b Institute of Physics & Department of Chemistry, Laboratory of Computational Materials, Federal University of Mato Grosso, 78060-900, Cuiabá, MT, Brazil Institute of Physics & Department of Chemistry Laboratory of Computational Materials Federal University of Mato Grosso Cuiabá MT 78060-900 Brazil Institute of Physics & Department of Chemistry, Laboratory of Computational Materials, Federal University of Mato Grosso, 78060-900, Cuiabá, MT, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The kinetics of lithium-oxygen batteries were elucidated, revealing a preferred oxygen reduction reaction on the Li2O2 surface during the initial stages of discharge. Lithium-oxygen batteries are a promising technology because they can greatly surpass the energy density of lithium-ion batteries. However, this theoretical characteristic has not yet been converted into a real device with high cyclability. Problems with air contamination, metallic lithium reactivity, and complex discharge and charge reactions are the main issues for this technology. A fast and reversible oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is crucial for good performance of secondary batteries’, but the partial knowledge of its mechanisms, especially when devices are concerned, hinders further development. From this perspective, the present work uses operando Raman experiments and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) to assess the first stages of the discharge processes in porous carbon electrodes, following their changes cycle by cycle at initial operation. A growth kinetic formation of the discharge product signal (Li2O2) was observed with operando Raman, indicating a first-order reaction and enabling an analysis by a microkinetic model. The solution mechanism in the evaluated system was ascribed for an equivalent circuit with three time constants. While the time constant for the anode interface reveals to remain relatively constant after the first discharge, its surface seemed to be more non-uniform. The model indicated that the reaction occurs at the Li2O2 surface, decreasing the associated resistance during the initial discharge phase. Furthermore, the growth of Li2O2 forms a hetero-phase between Li2O2/electrolyte, while creating a more compact and homogeneous on the Li2O2/cathode surface. The methodology here described thus offers a way of directly probing changes in surface chemistry evolution during cycling from a device through EIS analysis. Keywords Li-O2 battery Operando Raman analysis Equivalent circuit modeling Time-constant distribution 1 Introduction The Paris Climate Agreement released the challenge of keeping global warming below 2° C compared to pre-industrial levels [1]. Actions focused on reductions in energy-demand and agricultural emissions, decarbonization of electricity, and electrification of the transportations sector are cited as required to achieve this goal. Indeed, several global leader countries announced plans to phase out fuel-powered engines until 2050, resulting in increased interest in electric vehicles (EVs) [2]. Currently, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are the most commercialized system for portable energy storage applications. LIBs count on a safe, well-known, and high energy density technology (theoretical value of 387 W h/kg for the traditional graphite vs. LiCoO2) [3]. Although, alternative battery technologies like lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) can overpass LIBs in terms of theoretical energy density in almost 10 times, establishing a favorable system for the new generations of EVs batteries [4]. Although promising, lithium-oxygen batteries face problems that reduce the experimental capacity drastically. The use of the reactive metallic lithium as the anode, contaminations coming from the air, and the sluggish oxygen reaction kinetics are this battery's major challenges that alter the chemical evolution of the discharge products during cycling. Therefore, a deeper understanding of the main underlaying rate-limiting steps and the origin for the raising overpotentials are necessary to overcome them [5]. Two discharge reaction mechanisms are reported for aprotic electrolytes, i.e., the solution and the surface mechanism. The mechanism depends on current density, overpotential, and if the intermediate LiO2 is dissolved/solvated in the electrolyte or absorbed on the electrode [6]. These two mechanisms lead to different morphologies for the discharge product, which directly affects the discharge capacity [7]. The solution mechanism prolongs the discharge capacity due to the formation of toroid-like particles versus the film-like formation for the surface mechanism. The latter could accelerate the sudden death of the battery because of the semiconductor nature of Li2O2 and its compact film deposit, which grows until a critical value (∼5–10 nm) and completely blocks the charge transport [8]. Although, the incorporation of some catalysts can benefit the electron transfer and ion diffusion even in film-like deposition [9,10]. Another recent hypothesis is that for porous electrodes, pore-clogging and oxygen transport are responsible for cell death for both solution and film mechanisms [11,12]. Although, some prior research indicates that even though Li2O2 is predicted to be an electrical insulator, it can be metallic conductive when it has lithium vacancies [13]. Furthermore, the formation of large toroid particles (up to 1.0 μm) suggests that they can be electronically conductive at a relatively high thickness of Li2O2 [14]. Tong et al. [15] even observed a decrease in the activation energy of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the charge transfer resistance on the Li2O2 surface. This study uses electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) to analyze a Li-O2 system since it can separate electrochemical processes and evaluate direct interfaces as electrode/Li2O2 and Li2O2/electrolyte. Other studies, more representative of a Li-O2 battery, employed EIS and equivalent circuits for their evaluations [16–18]. Luntz et al. [16] also discussed that limitations in charge transport through the Li2O2 layer caused sudden death, and parasitic reactions were identified as a cause for the high overpotential. Another powerful technique to give insights into Li-O2 battery processes and to evaluate Li2O2 toroidal or film-thin presence is Raman spectroscopy, being used by many authors to detect the Li2O2 presence in ex-situ setups [19–23]. However, such an approach presents a lack of pivotal spectroscopy parameters (e.g., intensity, band shift, FWHM) along a galvanostatic discharge, and a mechanism evaluation is less representative. Operando Raman spectroscopy is a technique that can overcome ex-situ limitations, but is still not widely exploited in the literature [23,24]. Therefore, this present work aims to obtain fundamental insights into morphological and structural aspects of ignition and growing Li2O2 in Li-O2 device, by operando characterization, coupled with modeling EIS responses to postulate the origin of rate limiting steps during battery cycling. Ours results indicate that the Li2O2 formation at the first stages plays a crucial role on facilitating the oxygen reduction reaction creating a more active Li2O2/Electrolyte interface. On the other hand, its presence in a porous electrode, also increased the resistance at the Li2O2/Electrode interface. This increase happens cycle-by-cycle and represents a major challenge for the complete reversibility of the battery. 2 Materials and method 2.1 Gas diffusion electrodes synthesis The experimental cathodes were made of carbon fiber composite carbon paper (Toray Carbon Paper TGP-H-060) with a thickness of 0.05 mm. The carbon paper was punched into disks of φ 16 mm and dried in a furnace at 110 °C for 1 h before storage in an argon glovebox (MBRAUN, model LABstar) with parameters kept in H2O < 5 ppm and O2 < 10 ppm. 2.2 Cell assembly Electrochemical experiments were performed in a Li-O2 battery developed by the group [25–27]. The anode consisted of metallic lithium (Tob Machine, 99.99%), shaped in disks of φ 16 mm and thickness of 0.05 mm. The electrolyte was a 0.1 M LiClO4 solution in DMSO (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.99% anhydrous), which was further dried in molecular sieves (3 Å, Sigma-Aldrich) for > 3 days. The separator was made of glass fiber disks (φ 20 mm) (Whatman Millipore) and 90 μL of electrolyte was added to it. The cell assembly was performed in an argon glovebox and followed the sequence: negative current collector, anode, separator and electrolyte, gas diffusion electrode, spring, and positive current collector. After assembling, the cells were kept in the glovebox for 3 days before experimental procedures, to assure satisfactory wettability between cell components. Before the electrochemical experiments, 3 bars of oxygen were inserted into the cell (closed system). 2.3 Electrochemical experiments Electrochemical experiments were conducted using the PARSTAT 3000A-DXA potentiostat. The discharge experiments were carried out in the galvanostatic mode, the current density was 24.9 µA/cm2 (3.1 mA/g) and the cut-off was 2 V vs. Li/Li+. Discharge was applied twice; a three-hour discharge (i.e., cycle-1) for the first cycle and the second cycle was six-hour discharge (i.e., cycle-2). Galvanostatic linear sweep voltammetry (1 μA/s) was conducted, sweeping from -1 mA up to 1 mA. The investigations were done in triplicated batteries. The galvanostatic linear sweep voltammetry studies were described henceforward as pristine (prepared Li-O2 battery), cycle-1 (first discharge step), and cycle-2 (second discharge step). EIS experiments were taken in OCP values and in the same moments as described for the galvanostatic linear sweep voltammetry. EIS was also taken under three cathodic and two anodic potentials, chosen accordingly with the galvanostatic linear sweep experiment. The frequency range of 100 kHz to 10 mHz was swept by a small sinusoidal signal of 5 mV (peak-to-peak) to linearize the impedance response. Accurate simulations of the impedance data were accomplished using the complex non-linear least squares (CNLS) method, with an obtained relative error of less than 5% for each model’s parameter. Kramers-Krönig tests, characterized by low chi-square values (ca. χ 2 < 10−4), were accomplished to validate the impedance data. 2.4 Scanning electron microscopy The gas diffusion electrodes were disassembled from the electrochemical cell in an argon glovebox (Mbraun/Labstar) for microscopy and Raman characterization. The surface morphology was examined in a FEI high-speed Inspect F50 scanning electron microscope (SEM) from the Brazilian Nanotechnology National Laboratory (LNNano). 2.5 Operando Raman characterization The operando Raman characterization was performed at room temperature using the Renishaw in Via Raman spectroscope with He-Ne 632.8 nm (1.96 eV) at 0.3 mW power, 60 s, and 2 accumulations measurement conditions. A 50 × objective was employed, and the Raman shift was calibrated using the instrument’s internal silica positioned at 520.6 1/cm. The Li-O2 battery for Raman tests was assembled in a similar manner as described above in a cell designed for conducting Raman experiments. The cell consisted of a commercial El-Cell base and an in-house developed lid [27] with chambers for gas flow and a sapphire window. The components used in the assembly were the same, but with diameters that fit the Raman cell model, such as lithium disks of φ 9 mm, glass fiber separator of φ 10 mm, and gas diffusion electrode of φ 14 mm. Before the test, the battery was purged with 1.5 bar O2 gas, the maximum value supported by the window. The cell was discharged with a current density of 8 mA/g and a cut-off of 2 V vs. Li/Li+. Raman spectra were collected at open circuit potential, then every 15 min for up to 4 h. Spectra analyses were accomplished by proper subtraction of the baseline, deconvolution using Lorentzian distribution functions, and normalization by the intensity of the G band of carbon obtained for each spectrum. A microkinetic model, order and rate reactions were performed using integrated intensity Raman bands. Three ordinary differential equations (below discussed) were numerically solved by utilizing the RKF45 (Runge-Kutta-Fehlberg method) tool in Matlab software. In cases where the initial conditions were not specified, they were assumed to be 0. 3 Results and discussion In Fig. 1 (a and b) it is possible to observe the morphological and structural characterization, respectively. The microscopy image was obtained soon after the second discharge–charge cycle (i.e., the final condition of the Raman experiment), while the Raman was recorded in operando conditions. Fig. 1(a) displays toroidal morphology into the entire carbon paper substrate with diameter d L i 2 O 2 = 0.30 ± 0.065 μm and particle thickness h L i 2 O 2 = 800 ± 0.018 nm median values. Nazar et al. [28] studied the current density dependence of Li2O2 formation in the Li-O2 battery and its effect on charge. According to the authors [28], slow current densities lead to a solution-mediated mechanism related to the disproportionation, possibly due to the weak competitive binding of the LiO2 to the surface. This result is the nucleation of large toroidal nanocrystalline Li2O2 aggregates. Moreover, Nazar et al. [28] observed lateral dimensions of the toroidal particles up to 500 nm, in agreement with the values reported herein. Thompson et al. [29] investigated the shape evolution of disc to toroid particles at low discharge rates onto CNTs. The authors observed that disc-shapes evolve to toroidal shapes as the particle size increases. We obtained similar results in our experiments with 6-hour discharge, where SEM experiments revealed a disc-like shape for Li2O2, which evolved into a toroidal shape in 9-h discharge (see Fig. 1a). Also, the aspect ratio (ratio between particle thickness h and diameter d) increases as a function of the discharge current applied. The disc-shape evolution of Li2O2 particles towards toroidal morphology is related to the presence of growth along [001] direction and the presence of (100) and (110) diffraction planes. Finally, Li2O2 toroidal morphologies were also observed in carbon nanofibers [30], membranes [31] and activated carbon [32]. Although toroidal morphology can be used as proof of Li2O2 nanocrystalline particles, structural evidence such as Raman spectroscopy is fundamental from a chemical composition point of view. It is possible to notice in Fig. 1(b) the operando Raman spectra with discharging elapsed time for electrode substrate in a Li-O2 battery. As expected, at open circuit potential, bands related to carbon electrode and DMSO solvent electrolyte are observed. The bands located at 670 and 700 cm−1 are related to CS symmetric and antisymmetric stretch modes, respectively, and the feature at 1030 cm−1 corresponds to CH3 rocking modes, all of them from DMSO molecule [33–35]. Still regarding the electrolyte, the band at 930 cm−1 is assigned to the ClO stretch of LiClO4 mode [32]. Carbon band is present at 1335 cm−1, which is so-called D-band related to lattice structural defects, e.g., sp 3 hybridized valence in planar terminations of disordered graphite structure in carbon materials [36–38]. Along to the discharge spectra, in addition to DMSO and carbon features, a band at 785 cm−1, assigned to the OO stretching mode of Li2O2 [7,39–41], appears and increases from ∼7 to 28 mA h/g of capacity. Therefore, Li2O2 was qualitatively and quantitatively detected along discharging sweep. We must stress out that any band related to LiO2 (1137 cm−1) formation on the electrode surface was not observed at operando Raman spectra. Since the surface-model predicts the formation of solid LiO2 at the electrode surface as an intermediate specie, the surface-model does not apply to this system [42]. The deep discharge profile of carbon paper-based Li-O2 battery is presented in Fig. S1, once that it is one-magnitude order longer compared to Fig. 1(b). It is well described in the literature that the discharge reaction at the cathode can be proceed via either a surface mechanism or a solution mediated pathway [7,19,43,44]. (1) L i s o l + + O 2 g + e - k 1 ⇌ k - 1 L i O 2 ( a d s ) (2) L i s o l + + LiO 2 ( a d s ) + e - k 2 ⇌ k - 2 Li 2 O 2 ( ads ) or (3) Li sol + + O 2 g + e - k 1 ⇌ k - 1 LiO 2 ( sol ) (4) LiO 2 ( sol ) + Li + + e - k 2 ⇌ k - 2 Li 2 O 2 ( sol ) (5) 2 LiO 2 ( sol ) k 3 ⇌ k - 3 Li 2 O 2 ( sol ) + O 2 ( g ) These distinct mechanisms can be described as surface (Reactions (1), (2)) and solution (Reactions (3)–(5)) mechanisms. The “ads” and “sol” subscripts are related to adsorbed or solution presented species, respectively. In the surface mechanism, the lithium superoxide (LiO2) forms via one-electron O2 reduction, as observed in Reaction 1. In Fig. 1(b), the absence of any band related to LiO2 was observed throughout the discharge and charging processes. Therefore, it is suggested that the Li2O2 species presented here are related to the solution mechanism, as described in Reactions (3)–(5). Initially, there is a one-electron electrochemical reduction of O2 to form lithium superoxide (LiO2(ads)) at the surface (Reaction (3)), which then diffuses into solution. The LiO2(sol) species can react with lithium present in the electrolyte, forming Li2O2 (Reaction (4)) or it can undergo a disproportionation reaction, producing Li2O2(sol) and O2(g) (Reaction 5r.d.s, rate-determining step). Due to its limited solubility in the organic electrolyte, Li2O2 promptly precipitates from the solution, forming nuclei and gradually develop into toroidal Li2O2 aggregates, as observed previously in Fig. 1(a). The integrated intensity of Li2O2 obtained for discharging sweep is presented in Fig. 1(c). Therefore, kinetic order and rate constant information can be obtained for the integrated intensity of Li2O2 as described in Reaction 5r.d.s and displayed in Fig. 1(d), respectively. It is possible to observe a linear profile for the integrated intensity of Li2O2, which is described by a first-order reaction with good statistical convergence parameter (χ 2 = 0.97578). Moreover, the obtained rate constant was k 3 = 0.62 h−1. Supplementary information Fig. S2 also shows that coupled reactions do not agree with a second-order reaction protocol. According to Franco et al. [45–48] there may be differences between the phenomenon of superoxide disproportionation occurring on the electrode surface and within the electrolyte. The former resembles a surface catalysis mechanism, while the latter, which occurs in solution, is commonly classified as a second-order reaction. Hardwick et al. [49] revealed that the electrooxidation process of Li2O2, resulting from the surface disproportionation of superoxide, exhibits a zero-order reaction kinetics. On the other hand, Chen et al. [50], also using DMSO as electrolyte, observed that at elevated concentrations, the disproportionation of superoxide manifests as a first-order process (k 1 = 0.62 s−1), whereas at lower concentrations, it gradually assumes the characteristics of a second-order process (k 2 = 2.05 × 104 L/(mol s)). This intriguing behavior remains consistent regardless of the solvents employed, prompting the formulation of a potential mechanism to elucidate this disproportionation phenomenon. Prakash et al. [51] also observed that the surface disproportionation reaction dominates the kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction and suggested a microkinetic model to explain experimental observations regarding the cell discharge products. However, it must be stressed that, most of kinetic studies of Li-O2 batteries focus on a fundamental approach, using rotating disc-ring electrodes and proper electrochemical cell. To the best of our knowledge, no study has investigated the microkinetic model under battery devices conditions and thus make the available data difficult to correlate with the performance of a device. Based on data discussed above, the microkinetic model is presented in Fig. 1(d). Saturated O2 concentration was used as described by Foster et al. [52], who studied oxygen transport properties of organic electrolytes and performance of Li-O2 battery, and Bruce et al. [7], who studied the role of LiO2 solubility in O2 reduction in aprotic solvents and its consequences for Li-O2 batteries. It is possible to observe an exponential increase in Li2O2 along the microkinetic model, in agreement with Fig. 1(b). Concentration profiles were modeled up to 96 hours, and it is possible to observe 50% of Li2O2 coverage obtained at 55 h. LiO2 could not be observed in Fig. 1(b), as it acts as an intermediate species and shows a peak at 10 h, corresponding to 12% of its production, followed by an exponential decreasing. Since k 1 and k 2 could not be obtained using a proper Li-O2 battery device herein, and considering that most authors described k 1 and k 2 using different approaches (e.g. RRDE), we used as protocol k 1/k 2 = 1 (Fig. 1d), k 1/k 2 = 10 (Fig. S3) and k 1/k 2 = 0.1 (Fig. S4), as normally performed in kinetic studies. Fig. 2 (a) presents experiments of galvanostatic linear sweep voltammetry for three discharge steps. The batteries were swept through negative and positive currents at a slow velocity (1 μA/s) and a linear region was observed only for negative currents, i.e., in discharging processes (Fig. S5 presents a zoom for the galvanostatic linear sweep voltammetry to support this evaluation). Even though mechanism evaluation with Tafel plots cannot be done in transient conditions and non-ideal electrochemical systems [53], the comparison of current density versus potential plots can give some kinetic clues in different discharge states. Fig. 2(b) shows the slope of the linear region for each discharge step. The values are an average between triplicate batteries and the error are standard deviations, to avoid fluctuations caused by the multi-surface effects of porous electrodes [54]. Similar slope value (119 mV/dec) is reported for Li-O2 non-discharged in flat electrodes with diffusion in semi-infinite conditions [55,56] and battery-like electrochemical systems [16,17]. The highest slope value is given for the non-discharged battery, which decreases significantly after a short discharge (three hours). This could be caused by the activation energy decrease of ORR on the Li2O2, as proposed by Tong et al. [15]. Similarly, the increase in the slope observed after the initial stages of discharge can be attributed to the progressively deposition of non-conductive Li2O2 in the electrode. The Li2O2 particles obtained through carbon paper substrate led to two interfaces at the cathode electrode: electrode/Li2O2 (interior) and Li2O2/electrolyte (exterior) cases. In this sense, EIS is a powerful technique to study the contributions of both interfaces and the rate-limiting steps, which together with operando Raman and SEM, can guide into the present analysis of how the microstructural morphology affects the ORR at the Li2O2 sites. Tong et al. [15] developed a numerical model for interfacial impedance related to exterior and interior case. According to the authors [15], the interfacial impedance for exterior case i.e., the Li2O2/electrolyte interface, can be described as (6) Z int ex = 1 ρ Li 2 O 2 d Li 2 O 2 + j ω n 1 C Li 2 O 2 - 1 + F i ORR 0 RT + j ω n 2 C dl 1 - λ Li + 1 + λ O 2 + λ Li + - 1 + l Li + σ e 1 - tan h Ω e l Li + Ω e l Li + The film capacitance is given by the expression C Li 2 O 2 = ε 0 ε Li 2 O 2 / d Li 2 O 2 . The first term in parentheses on the right-hand side corresponds to charge transport and double layer effects across the Li2O2 layer, with ρ Li 2 O 2 , d Li 2 O 2 , ε Li 2 O 2 being the resistivity, thickness, and dielectric constant of the Li2O2 layer, respectively. The exponential factor ni (0 < ni < 1) account for the non-ideality of the double-layer (constant phase element). The second term describes the ORR charge transfer reaction and double-layer charging on the Li2O2-electrolyte interface, with i ORR 0 as the exchange current density. The double layer capacitance is C dl and λ O 2 and λ Li + reflect the effects of transport of oxygen and Li+ in the bulk solution on the kinetics of the ORR, respectively. The third term described the impedance of Li+ transport from the solution to the reacting interface. The interfacial impedance for the interior case, i.e., ORR on the electrode/Li2O2 interface, can be described as (7) Z int in = F i ORR 0 RT + j ω n 2 C dl 1 - λ Li + Li 2 O 2 1 + λ O 2 Li 2 O 2 + λ Li + Li 2 O 2 - 1 + Z d Li 2 O 2 + Z d e The first term in the right side considers double-layer effects on the interface electrode/Li2O2 and charge transfer resistance, with λ O 2 Li 2 O 2 and λ Li + Li 2 O 2 corresponding to the effective transport of oxygen and Li+ in the Li2O2 layer. The second term describes the impedance transport of Li+ through the Li2O2 layer, which is porous and allows the transport of oxygen and ions. The electronic transport through this layer is neglected, since the reaction is in contact with the electrode. Z d e is the third term in the right side of the Eq. (6). As a result, Tong et al. [15] simulations exhibit two semicircles for the exterior case, with a high-frequency one corresponding to the Li2O2 layer and a low-frequency one corresponding to the Li2O2/electrolyte interface. On the other hand, the interior case exhibit only one semicircle corresponding to the electrode/Li2O2 interface. Once that Z int ex and Z int in presents notable impedance spectra differences, it is possible to scrutinize the interface along the discharge process and infer about the reacting interface. It is important to stress out that, both Eqs. (6) and (7) are related to the interfacial impedance for the interior and exterior case, respectively. It means that such impedance profile takes account on the working electrode (carbon nanostructure), whereas cathodic are probed. However, for a proper Li-O2 battery, a more complex model is necessary, where anode reactions and interface membrane (anode/cathode spacer) is placed. The OCP values were measured as a function of state of discharge and obtained values were pristine = 2.844 V, cycle-1 = 2.869 V and cycle-2 = 2.871 V. Therefore, it is possible to notice a new electrochemical interface forming and remaining along discharge steps. The Nyquist spectra in Fig. 3 (a) - inset display a large semicircle at low- frequency and other at high-frequency values. More processes are evident at the Bode spectra, whereas it is possible to recognize three time constants, i.e., related to each semicircle presented for each all OCP conditions. Similar electrochemical impedance spectra were noticed in the literature for Li-O2 batteries [16–18]. A high-frequency (∼104 Hz) band was observed with a small magnitude, a middle band at mid-frequency (∼102–103 Hz), and an intense band with a large magnitude at low frequency (∼10− 2–100 Hz). As above mentioned, Tong et al. [15] studied the numerical modeling of Eq. (6) (exterior case) and Eq. (7) (interior case). The authors observed similar spectra exhibited in Fig. 3(a) using Eq. (6) i.e., the electrochemical mechanism observed for the presented operational Li-O2 battery is related to the exterior case. Because of the Bode spectra displayed in Fig. 3(a) presents the process explained in Eq. (6), it is possible to suggest that the ORR takes place at the Li2O2/electrolyte interface. If the present electrochemical system followed the same tendencies as described by Tong et al. [15], it would be expected that the ORR (low frequency processes) was observed only after discharge-steps, i.e., as soon as the Li2O2 (seen by an increase in mid-frequency band) is deposited as toroidal nanoparticles onto carbon paper. Indeed, in Fig. 3(a) a large band observed in the low frequency is only well observed at cycle-1 and cycle-2, with values of FWHMOCP-1 = 1.80 Hz < FWHMOCP-2 = 3.60 Hz. The intensity of this band is reduced in the discharge steps, suggesting that the resistance associated with ORR is decreasing. On the other hand, the magnitude of the mid-frequency process increases as a function of the discharge–charge step (pristine < cycle-1 < cycle-2), suggesting the accumulation of the Li2O2. Therefore, based on data presented in Fig. 1, numerical modeling of Equation (6), and Bode spectra presented in Fig. 3(a), it is possible to suggest that mid-frequency (∼102–103 Hz) are related to charge transport and double layer effects into Li2O2/electrolyte interface, and intense band with large magnitude at low-frequency (∼10−2–100 Hz) related to ORR for the operational Li-O2 battery. Additionally, even though Li2O2 is massively considered a hindrance for Li-O2 battery deep discharge, mainly due to its insulator property (E band-gap > 4.2–4.5 eV), lower ionic conductivity (σ = 10−7–10−11 S/cm) and amorphous structure, it was observed herein that Li2O2 facilitates the charge transfer in the ORR. In a two-electrode cell, like presented herein, it is necessary to separate the anode and cathode impedances contribution in order to infer physical–chemical properties (e.g., interface, morphology and time constants) based on the equivalent circuit. Therefore, the impedances at OCP were measured under argon atmosphere i.e., inhibit the oxygen reduction/oxidation and O2. Under these conditions (argon or O2 atmosphere) both electrode (LiAnode and carbon paper Cathode) would be affected differently. Finally, it is possible to observe at Fig. S6 the absence of both processes (Li2O2 structure and ORR) described, whereas presented a Bode spectra in the absence of O2. Such results corroborate with finds described in Fig. 1 and Fig. 3. Soon after, all electrochemical impedance spectra presented in Fig. 3(a) were numerically modeled using the equivalent circuit described in Fig. 3(b), and simulation statistics (e.g., validated F, t-tests, and χ 2 = 5.0 × 10−4) was achieved. Although the Li2O2 and carbon nanostructure presented a porous structure, any impedance spectra presenting transmission line model [57,58] was observed for the system studied herein. Different from Tong et al. [15], the present equivalent circuit models a realistic Li-O2 battery (i.e., non-planar electrodes, two-electrode measurements and non-semi-infinite diffusion), and further electrochemical processes needs to be considered. In the equivalent circuit exhibited, Z1 (CPE1 and r 1) are related to anode and both, Z2 (CPE2 and r 2) and Z3 (CPE3 and r 3) related to the cathode. More specifically, Z2 is a combination of interface carbon paper and electronic transport and Z 3 is a combination of the charge transfer reaction of oxygen reduction and the electronic transport through the Li2O2. The process of Li+ diffusion and crossover through the membrane can be observed in the circuit as rs. As described previously, Z 1 are related to the anode process, Luntz et al. [16] investigated the overpotential in Li-O2 batteries using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. The authors also described similar equivalent circuit as presented in Fig. 3(b). Furthermore, EIS measurement in a just-assembled Li-O2 battery still in argon atmosphere still showed the Z2 process, which corroborate its independence from oxygen reduction reaction. Anandan et al. [17] studied the evaluation and electrochemical analyses of cathodes for Li-O2 batteries. The authors also observed a band at Bode spectra in the 10−1–1.0 Hz frequency range and identified this process at the cathode element. Therefore, under such boundary conditions, the remaining presence of Z2 suggest that this process is not related to oxygen reduction but connects with the carbon/electrolyte interface. Multiple electrochemical processes with a wide range of time-constants occur in batteries. In addition to the charge transfer processes of the individual electrodes, diffusion processes such as of lithium ions through the surface films of the electrodes and within active material also influence the dynamic characteristics of batteries [59]. The diffusion branch at low frequencies is generally assigned to the mass transfer effects as the time constant of these processes is usually a few decades larger compared to other dynamic processes [59]. Charge transfer processes and the lithium diffusion trough the Li2O2 cause a semicircle in the spectra [60]. Since the time-constants are of a comparable order of magnitude, these processes show overlapping effects in the impedance spectra and only a single semicircle is visible. Therefore, fitting electrochemical impedance spectra using equivalent circuit and obtaining proper time-constant values is a powerful technique in order to analyze whole process in battery devices. According to the equivalent circuit presented in Fig. 3(b), three time constants (Anode 1: τ anode=1 = r anode∙q anode, Cathode 2:τ interface=2 = r inter∙q inter and Cathode 3:τ exterior=3 = r ct∙q dl) can be obtained for each spectrum e.g., pristine, cycle-1 and cycle-2 and its values are displayed in Fig. 3(c). It is possible to notice larger time-constant for anode process compared to cathode ones and, its values (τ anode) remain constant after first (cycle-1) and second (cycle-2) discharge–charge steps. Such apparent stable time-constant values can be related to lower kinetic of SEI formation at the anode and the non-porous blocking structure compared to cathode electrode [61–63].This is expected especially considering that positive galvanostatic currents were not applied in this study, only small positive overpotentials (maximum of 0.3 V) for EIS analysis in short times (∼20 min). Considering cathode processes, time-constant obtained for interfacial phenomena (τ interface) are superior to those related to exterior process i.e., oxygen reduction reaction onto Li2O2 deposits. Moreover, it is important to stress out that lower exterior time-constant values (τ exterior) were obtained at thicker and larger Li2O2 deposits i.e., cycle-2. To our knowledge, no study has been conducted on the fundamental contribution of each time constant (anode and cathode) accomplish to operando Raman for Li-O2 batteries. Kowal et al. [64] studied the distribution of time-constants by means of pulse evaluation for offline and online diagnosis of lithium-ion batteries. Moreover, the method was experimentally validated using EIS. The authors [64] obtained three time constants during a charge pulse with constant current and the subsequent relaxation period using distribution of relaxation times (DRT) approach. At the beginning of the relaxation process, all processes contribute to changes in cell voltage. However, as relaxation progresses, only processes with larger time constants are relevant. In this sense, separate ranges of time constant are expected. According to the authors [64], distributions reveal relevant processes with time constants in the range of 2 × 10−3 < τ < 2 × 100 s. According to f = (1/2π τ), these time constants approximately correspond to frequencies between 0.1 and 100 Hz. Processes in this frequency range were assigned to charge transfer [65–68] and surface films of the electrodes [65,69], typically processes expected at the cathode surface. The Li-O2 battery was submitted to two discharge steps, namely cycle-1 and cycle-2, respectively. The value in open circuit was cycle-1 = 2.871 V and cycle-2 = 2.869 V and EIS measurements were taken in anodic potentials (3.15 and 2.98 V) and cathodic potentials (2.85, 2.80 and 2.75 V). The potentials were chosen based in Tafel plots presented in Fig. 2(a) in the region of low overpotentials, aiming a kinetic limitation for discharge, so the change in EIS bands is expected to be more related with ORR processes. Since charging conditions did not result in linear profiles, sufficiently small overpotentials were taken, but avoiding cathodic reactions contributions. It is possible to notice in Fig. 4 (a) the absence band at Bode spectra along 10−1–100 Hz for both, cycle-1 and cycle-2 at 3.15 and 2.98 V. However, at cathodic voltages, it is possible to observe a band arise at 2.85, 2.80 and 2.75 V for both, cycle-1, and cycle-2. Therefore, in charging potentials the charge transfer and electronic transport through the Li2O2 cannot be seen by this low frequency band. This suggests that the charge mechanism is not correspondent of the discharge mechanism in this Li-O2 setup, as also discussed by other authors [70,71]. In addition, the characteristic frequency shifted towards lower values comparing cycle-1 and cycle-2 e.g., f cycle-1 2.85 V = 0.30 Hz < f cycle-2 2.85 V = 1.30 Hz and f cycle-1 2.80 V = 0.50 Hz < f cycle-2 2.80 V = 2.20 Hz. Therefore, the increase in characteristic frequency is related to decrease in time-constant values. As a result, the oxygen reduction reaction is promptness to occur at cycle-2, once that is already possible to observe Li2O2 toroidal particles, as depicted in Fig. 1(a). The influence of apparent roughness (α < 1) still is a controversial issue concerning the meaning of constant phase element. While CPEs are commonly used to improve the fit to experimental impedance spectra, the explanation for their origin has been largely conjectural. Tribollet et al. [72] studied the CPE analysis by local EIS. According to the authors [72], the CPE has a distribution of time-constants through a film or along an electrode surface. The charge transfer resistance and surface distribution of capacitance has also contribution to apparent roughness values, as suggested by Sluyters et al. [73]. This model is associated to an irregular current and potential distribution onto an electrode surface. Many other factors can be related to the arisen of apparent roughness (α < 1), such as porous electrode structure [54,74,75], specific adsorption [76], surface roughness [77,78], atomic scale heterogeneity [79] and fractal theory [80–82]. More recently and based on advance of numerical computing, Ozarem et al. [83] studied the influence of roughness along the contribution of surface distribution to constant phase element using finite element method. According to the authors [83], a constant phase element associated with a surface distribution of time constants cannot be attributed to surface roughness. Therefore, adequate attention to the interface electrode/electrolyte interface must be considered carefully. Fig. 4(b) presents the apparent roughness obtained for CPE-1 (αCPE-1), CPE-2 (αCPE-2) and CPE-3 (αCPE-3) described in equivalent circuit (Fig. 3b) for cycle-1 and cycle-2. Surprisingly, the αCPE-1 and αCPE-3 are similar in phase and magnitude. Therefore, the anode oxidation process led to a non-uniform surface obtained onto Li-foil and a hetero-phase obtained at Li2O2/electrolyte cathode surface. The Li-anode morphology change significantly during repeated stripping and plating e.g., mossy (compact porous microstructures) dendritic growth (spiny projections growing outward from the Li metal surface) can be obtained at lower and higher current densities, respectively [84,85]. Moreover, the decreasing observed for αCPE-1 and αCPE-3 coincide with the increase of αCPE-2 values. As a result, a more compact and homogenous surface is obtained into cathode structure (Z 2), which is a combination of interface carbon paper and electronic transport. Similar profiles were observed for cycle 2 for all apparent roughness i.e., α CPE-1, α CPE-2, α CPE-3. However, in contrast to cycle-1, α CPE-3 presents higher non-uniformity related to apparent roughness compared to α CPE-1 values obtained in cycle 2. It can be related to higher non-uniform surface obtained during oxygen reduction reaction. Freitas et al. [86] studied the influence of water spitting into TiO2-nanotubes towards apparent roughness values. The authors observed that, the increase of photocurrent and, consequently, more oxygen reduction reaction kinetic lead to a significantly decrease of apparent roughness. Similar results were observed in the present case, whereas as discussed previously, Z 2 is related to a combination of the charge transfer reaction of oxygen reduction and the electronic transport through the Li2O2. Therefore, the oxygen reduction is a pivotal electrochemical property towards decreasing apparent roughness values, as observed for α CPE-3 cycle-1. Furthermore, once that oxygen reduction takes place at the cathode, α CPE-1 remains constant (even for cycle-2) and α CPE-3 decrease 33% due to oxygen reduction reaction. 4 Conclusions In this study, the initial stages of Li2O2 formation were unravel at a cell level, and their kinetics were discussed through a combination of EIS analysis with operando Raman. This approach provides insights into the Li-O2 electrochemical behavior and its correlation with the surface mechanism, observing changes cycle by cycle. A preliminary comparison between theoretical analysis and the acquired experimental results indicates that the ORR occurs in the Li2O2/electrolyte interface. During the initial moments of discharge, a decrease in resistance associated with the ORR is observed, accompanied by a reduction in the Tafel slope for the same stages. This behavior suggests a possible kinetic benefit due to the Li2O2 surface. The use of carbon paper as oxygen diffusion electrodes and high donor solvent as the electrolyte resulted in the formation of toroid-shaped discharge products at low current densities for the studied Li-O2 battery. Operando Raman experiments confirmed the solution mechanism and revealed a first-order reaction for the rate-determining step of the discharge process. Further assessment using equivalent circuit modeling was performed and three time constants were assigned. The low-frequency time constant was attributed to the carbon paper interface and electron transfer through it. The mid-frequency time constant was associated with charge transfer and the electron transportation through Li2O2, and the high-frequency time constant was related to the anode interface. EIS experiments applying overpotential revealed different spectra for cathodic and anodic currents. For the latter, the time constant related to the charge transfer and electronic transport was not observed. Additionally, rugosity evaluation revealed a non-uniform surface on the Li-foil and a hetero-phase obtained at the Li2O2/electrolyte cathode surface. In contrast, a more compact and homogeneous surface is described for the carbon paper/Li2O2 interface. This highlights the potential for probing changes in surface chemistry and mechanisms at a cell level, which is a crucial information for assessing the device's state of health and enhancing our understanding of the cycling process. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-oxygen batteries are a promising technology because they can greatly surpass the energy density of lithium-ion batteries. However, this theoretical characteristic has not yet been converted into a real device with high cyclability. Problems with air contamination, metallic lithium reactivity, and complex discharge and charge reactions are the main issues for this technology. A fast and reversible oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is crucial for good performance of secondary batteries’, but the partial knowledge of its mechanisms, especially when devices are concerned, hinders further development. From this perspective, the present work uses operando Raman experiments and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) to assess the first stages of the discharge processes in porous carbon electrodes, following their changes cycle by cycle at initial operation. A growth kinetic formation of the discharge product signal (Li2O2) was observed with operando Raman, indicating a first-order reaction and enabling an analysis by a microkinetic model. The solution mechanism in the evaluated system was ascribed for an equivalent circuit with three time constants. While the time constant for the anode interface reveals to remain relatively constant after the first discharge, its surface seemed to be more non-uniform. The model indicated that the reaction occurs at the Li2O2 surface, decreasing the associated resistance during the initial discharge phase. Furthermore, the growth of Li2O2 forms a hetero-phase between Li2O2/electrolyte, while creating a more compact and homogeneous on the Li2O2/cathode surface. The methodology here described thus offers a way of directly probing changes in surface chemistry evolution during cycling from a device through EIS analysis.
